result.markdown:
--- title: "ANOVA and linear models" description: "are these the same?" author: - name: An Bui url: https://an-bui.com/ affiliation: UC Santa Barbara, Ecology, Evolution, and Marine Biology affiliation-url: https://www.eemb.ucsb.edu/ freeze: auto categories: [ANOVA, linear models] citation: url: https://an-bui.github.io/ES-193DS-W23/resources/anova-vs-lm.html --- # Set up ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(flextable) library(emmeans) ``` ::: # Context ANOVAs and linear models are very similar - in fact, they are basically the same thing. This is because ANOVAs can be considered a case of a linear model where the predictor is categorical. We can see this with some fake data: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(666) df <- cbind( # generating data that will for sure be different in means x = rnorm(n = 35, mean = 3, sd = 1), y = rnorm(n = 35, mean = 10, sd = 1), z = rnorm(n = 35, mean = 5, sd = 1) ) %>% # make this a data frame as_tibble() %>% # put it into long format pivot_longer(cols = x:z) %>% rename("group" = name) ``` ::: Just to visualize: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = df, aes(x = group, y = value)) + geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.25, height = 0, seed = 666), alpha = 0.5, shape = 21) + stat_summary(geom = "point", fun = mean, color = "darkorange", size = 4) + theme_light() + theme(text = element_text(size = 14)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](anova-vs-lm_files/figure-html/plotting-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: And summarize (only means, because that's what we care about): ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df %>% group_by(group) %>% summarize(mean = round(mean(value), digits = 3)) %>% flextable() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

group

mean

x

2.815

y

10.118

z

4.849

``` ::: ::: And now trying an ANOVA: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # ANOVA object anova <- aov(value ~ group, data = df) # summary table summary(anova) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) group 2 994.6 497.3 450.3 <2e-16 *** Residuals 102 112.7 1.1 --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Tukey post-hoc test TukeyHSD(anova) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Tukey multiple comparisons of means 95% family-wise confidence level Fit: aov(formula = value ~ group, data = df) $group diff lwr upr p adj y-x 7.303894 6.706373 7.901415 0 z-x 2.034339 1.436819 2.631860 0 z-y -5.269555 -5.867075 -4.672034 0 ``` ::: ::: And a linear model: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # linear model linmod <- lm(value ~ group, data = df) # summary of model summary(linmod) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = value ~ group, data = df) Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -2.79214 -0.79635 0.06151 0.60149 2.33544 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) 2.8146 0.1776 15.844 < 2e-16 *** groupy 7.3039 0.2512 29.073 < 2e-16 *** groupz 2.0343 0.2512 8.098 1.25e-12 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 1.051 on 102 degrees of freedom Multiple R-squared: 0.8983, Adjusted R-squared: 0.8963 F-statistic: 450.3 on 2 and 102 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16 ``` ::: ::: Ok, so let's stop there and compare `summary(linmod)` to the mean summary table. If you imagine that a line formula is $$ y = mx + b $$ then you can read the `(Intercept)` estimate as $b$, and the estimates for the other two groups as the values for the means. Essentially, you now have: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df %>% mutate(new_group = case_when( group == "x" ~ "intercept", group %in% c("y", "z") ~ "slope" )) %>% ggplot(aes(x = new_group, y = value, group = group)) + geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.25, height = 0, seed = 666), alpha = 0.5, shape = 21) + stat_summary(geom = "point", fun = mean, color = "darkorange", size = 4) + geom_line() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](anova-vs-lm_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} theme_light() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` List "class")= chr [1:2] "theme" "gg" - attr(*, "complete")= logi TRUE - attr(*, "validate")= logi TRUE ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} anova(linmod) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Analysis of Variance Table Response: value Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) group 2 994.63 497.31 450.26 < 2.2e-16 *** Residuals 102 112.66 1.10 --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} contrast(emmeans(linmod, ~ group), method = "tukey") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` contrast estimate SE df t.ratio p.value x - y -7.30 0.251 102 -29.073 <.0001 x - z -2.03 0.251 102 -8.098 <.0001 y - z 5.27 0.251 102 20.975 <.0001 P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 3 estimates ``` ::: :::
